abstract.t: An extension to POP3 allowing opened connections to be shelved via a sleeping state, avoiding the const of repeated TCP and TLS handshakes when polling for new messages.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: When polling new new messages in a POP3 mailbox, both client and server need to repeatedly re-negotitate TCP and TLS connections as well as re-authenticating every time. Clients need to find a balance between polling too quickly and placing a corresponding burden on systems, and polling too slowly and messages not arriving in a timely manner.

By allowing a client, once it has completed downloading and deleting messages from the mailbox, to put a connection to sleep instread of closing it down, the client is at liberty to resume using the opened connection and so avoid the burden of all the steps needed to reconnect.
This extension introduces a new state, SLEEP, alongside the established states: AUTHORIZATION, TRANSACTION and UPDATE.

POP3 is designed to work on a simple bulk-download-and-delete model, eschewing more advanced features such as folder management. This extension is compatible with that model as the high-level operation of client and server is unchanged, only adding the ability to shelve opened connections between polls.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capability
section.t: A service implementing this extension indicates support by including the capability "SLEEPING" in response to a CAPA command.

list.t: SLEE in TRANSACTION, WAKE in SLEEP
The SLEEP capability indicates the optional SLEE and WAKE commands are available and the SLEEP state is supported.

section.title: The SLEEP State
section.t: This RFC introduces the SLEEP state, alongside the established states of AUTHORIZATION, TRANSACTION and UPDATE. An opened connection enters the SLEEP state on a +OK success response to a SLEE command and leaves it on a +OK response to a WAKE or QUIT command.
During the SLEEP state, the server MUST support these commands: NOOP, QUIT, WAKE.

list.t: NOTE: This document STRONGLY encourages that during a sleep state, service implementations return error responses to any command other that the three listed above, even if that service could perform the requested command. This will assist those developing clients from wrongly assuming commands such STAT or UIDL could be used during a SLEEP state to poll for new messages.

NOTE: This document STRONGLY encourages services that place a lock on a mailbox during a TRANSACTION state, rejecting concurrent requests, release those locks during a SLEEP state and allow other concurrent requests. It is permitted for the WAKE command to fail with a -ERR failure response if a separate connection has taken the lock for the mailbox during the SLEEP state.

section.title: Considerations for other capabilities
section.t: CAPA is not on the list of commands that are valid to use during the SLEEP state.

Registered capabilities include a statement to which states each capability may be announced in, often using "both" as a shorthand for "both the AUTHOIZATION and TRANSACTION states". As this document does not introduce a new state when the CAPA command may be used, this document does not change the meaning of the capabilities registered.

section.title: The SLEE Command
section.t:
The POP3 SLEE command requests that the POP3 service take the following steps:
All actions that take place on a successful QUIT command and UPDATE state, except for closing down the channel over which commands and responses are sent and received.
The connection transitions to the SLEEP state.
If the service cannot perform these steps, it MUST return an error (-ERR) response and leave the state of the mailbox and opened connection unchanged.

On the succesful completion of the SLEE command including successful transition to the SLEEP state, the service MUST respond with a success response (+OK) to indicate to the client it's request was succesful. A client MUST wait for a response before sending additional commands, regardless of the PIPELINING capability.

list.t: NOTE: Messages flagged for deletion by DELE are finally deleted by the SLEE command as well as by the QUIT command. Other POP3 extensions might allow for a mailbox to be modifed, but similar to DELE, the modification is documented to be diferred until committed by a QUIT command. In this case, those modifications would be committed by the SLEE command too. The only difference between SLEE is QUIT is that with SLEE, the communciations channel, including TCP and TLS, remain open.

figure.preamble: The <artwork> element has a number of extra attributes that can be used to substitute a more aesthetically pleasing rendition into HTML output while continuing to use the ASCII art version in the text and nroff outputs (see the xml2rfc README for details). It also has a "type" attribute. This is currently ignored except in the case 'type="abnf"'. In this case the "artwork" is expected to contain a piece of valid Augmented Backus-Naur Format (ABNF) grammar. This will be syntax checked by xml2rfc and any errors will cause a fatal error if the "strict" processing instruction is set to "yes". The ABNF will also be colorized in HTML output to highlight the syntactic components. Checking of additional "types" may be provided in future versions of xml2rfc.
